comment_text.mn92:1.1: This entire sutta is repeated at Snp 3.7.
comment_text.mn92:3.1: Keṇiya features also in the Vinaya, where at this point he offered the Buddha and the Sangha a drink in the evening, reasoning that the Brahmanical sages of the past did likewise (Kd 6:35.1.2). As a result, the Buddha allowed fruit juice and other drinks in the evening.
comment_text.mn92:4.4: “Manual preparations” is kāyaveyyāvaṭikaṁ. Ten kinds of service are enumerated in the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 9.24.
comment_text.mn92:7.2: Aṅga was subject to Magadha at that time. | This passage is partially echoed in the account of Anāthapiṇḍika’s conversion (Kd 16:4.1.10).
comment_text.mn92:9.1: Anāthapiṇḍika responded in the same way when hearing of the Buddha (Kd 16:4.2.10). Also compare Bāvari’s elation at Snp 5.1:19.1.
comment_text.mn92:12.4: Durāsada (“intimidating”) is also at AN 4.42:4.1, which shows that the sense is that they are hard to defeat in debate.
comment_text.mn92:15.3: As his verses make clear, Sela has not ruled out the possibility that Gotama’s destiny is to become a wheel-turning monarch rather than a Buddha.
comment_text.mn92:15.5: This idea is not found elsewhere in the Pali.
comment_text.mn92:16.1: These are also found in Sela’s verses at Thag 16.6.
comment_text.mn92:17.4: This is of course a reference to the first sermon (SN 56.11).
comment_text.mn92:18.5: The title “General of the Dhamma” belongs to Sāriputta (Ud 2.8:16.2, Thag 18.1:33.1).
comment_text.mn92:19.5: Anujāta is said at Iti 74:4.1 to be a child who “takes after” the good qualities of their parents.
comment_text.mn92:19.13: Abhiṇhaso means “repeatedly”. Here the force of the saying is, I think, “It is hard enough to encounter a Buddha even once, let alone repeatedly.”
comment_text.mn92:20.8: The “dark class” refers to those born in an unfortunate state (AN 6.57:11.1). Sela is saying that the Buddha’s path is for everyone, not just the fortunate.
comment_text.mn92:26.1: Yaññā is a truncated genitive plural (“of sacrifices”).| Mukha means originally “mouth”, hence “opening”, “entrance”; but also “face”, hence “front”, “foremost”. The fire is the foremost sacrifice, but fire is also a “mouth”, since “however much one may put into a fire, it burns it all up all” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.14.8). This sense of “consume” or “subsume” is alive in these verses as well. For example, the Sāvitrī “subsumes” other hymns, for merely one line is equivalent to all three Vedas (5.14.2).
comment_text.mn92:26.2: The Sāvitrī (or Gāyatrī) is a famous verse recited daily by brahmin priests at dawn: “Might we make our own that desirable effulgence of god Savitar, who will rouse forth our insights” (Rig Veda 3.62.10, Jamison/Brereton). It was the “head” of metres (śiro gāyatryaḥ, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 8.6.2.3, 8.6.2.6), and was “praised as the foremost of recitations” (gāyatrāṇy uktha mukhanai śaṁsanti, Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa 17.7.1). It was the first verse taught a new initiate (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.4.13). | Chandas can be either “meter” or a metrical song of praise, especially a Vedic hymn. The Sāvitrī is a Vedic text, not a meter, so the latter meaning must apply here. Its root is “desire”, retaining the sense of “prayer” as a song of praise and supplication.
comment_text.mn92:28.6: This verse and the next are also at Snp 3.6:49.1.

root_text.mn92:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā aṅguttarāpesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi yena āpaṇaṁ nāma aṅguttarāpānaṁ nigamo tadavasari.
root_text.mn92:2.2: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito aṅguttarāpesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi āpaṇaṁ anuppatto.
root_text.mn92:2.3: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
root_text.mn92:2.4: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
root_text.mn92:2.5: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn92:2.6: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.mn92:2.7: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī”ti.
root_text.mn92:3.1: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn92:3.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn92:3.3: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho keṇiyaṁ jaṭilaṁ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṁsesi.
root_text.mn92:3.4: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṁsito bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn92:3.5: “adhivāsetu me bhavaṁ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
root_text.mn92:3.6: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā keṇiyaṁ jaṭilaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn92:3.7: “mahā kho, keṇiya, bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni, tvañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno”ti.
root_text.mn92:3.8: Dutiyampi kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn92:3.9: “kiñcāpi kho, bho gotama, mahā bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni, ahañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno;
root_text.mn92:3.10: adhivāsetu me bhavaṁ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
root_text.mn92:3.11: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā keṇiyaṁ jaṭilaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn92:3.12: “mahā kho, keṇiya, bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni, tvañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno”ti.
root_text.mn92:3.13: Tatiyampi kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn92:3.14: “kiñcāpi kho, bho gotama, mahā bhikkhusaṅgho aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatāni, ahañca brāhmaṇesu abhippasanno;
root_text.mn92:3.15: adhivāsetu me bhavaṁ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
root_text.mn92:4.1: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavato adhivāsanaṁ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena sako assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mittāmacce ñātisālohite āmantesi:
root_text.mn92:4.3: samaṇo me gotamo nimantito svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena.
root_text.mn92:4.5: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho keṇiyassa jaṭilassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā keṇiyassa jaṭilassa paṭissutvā appekacce uddhanāni khaṇanti, appekacce kaṭṭhāni phālenti, appekacce bhājanāni dhovanti, appekacce udakamaṇikaṁ patiṭṭhāpenti, appekacce āsanāni paññapenti.
root_text.mn92:4.6: Keṇiyo pana jaṭilo sāmaṁyeva maṇḍalamālaṁ paṭiyādeti.
root_text.mn92:5.1: Tena kho pana samayena selo brāhmaṇo āpaṇe paṭivasati tiṇṇaṁ vedānaṁ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṁ sākkharappabhedānaṁ itihāsapañcamānaṁ, padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo, tīṇi ca māṇavakasatāni mante vāceti.
root_text.mn92:6.1: Tena kho pana samayena keṇiyo jaṭilo sele brāhmaṇe abhippasanno hoti.
root_text.mn92:6.2: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo tīhi māṇavakasatehi parivuto jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena keṇiyassa jaṭilassa assamo tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn92:6.3: Addasā kho selo brāhmaṇo keṇiyassa jaṭilassa assame appekacce uddhanāni khaṇante, appekacce kaṭṭhāni phālente, appekacce bhājanāni dhovante, appekacce udakamaṇikaṁ patiṭṭhāpente, appekacce āsanāni paññapente, keṇiyaṁ pana jaṭilaṁ sāmaṁyeva maṇḍalamālaṁ paṭiyādentaṁ.
root_text.mn92:7.2: “kiṁ nu bhoto keṇiyassa āvāho vā bhavissati vivāho vā bhavissati mahāyañño vā paccupaṭṭhito, rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro nimantito svātanāya saddhiṁ balakāyenā”ti?
root_text.mn92:8.1: “Na me, bho sela, āvāho bhavissati napi vivāho bhavissati napi rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro nimantito svātanāya saddhiṁ balakāyena;
root_text.mn92:8.2: api ca kho me mahāyañño paccupaṭṭhito.
root_text.mn92:8.3: Atthi, bho, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito aṅguttarāpesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi āpaṇaṁ anuppatto.
root_text.mn92:8.4: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
root_text.mn92:8.5: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
root_text.mn92:8.6: So me nimantito svātanāya bhattaṁ saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
root_text.mn92:10.3: Āgatāni kho panamhākaṁ mantesu dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveyeva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
root_text.mn92:10.4: Sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
root_text.mn92:10.6: cakkaratanaṁ, hatthiratanaṁ, assaratanaṁ, maṇiratanaṁ, itthiratanaṁ, gahapatiratanaṁ, pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
root_text.mn92:10.7: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
root_text.mn92:10.8: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
root_text.mn92:10.9: Sace pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado”.
root_text.mn92:11.1: “Kahaṁ pana, bho keṇiya, etarahi so bhavaṁ gotamo viharati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti?
root_text.mn92:11.2: Evaṁ vutte, keṇiyo jaṭilo dakkhiṇaṁ bāhuṁ paggahetvā selaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn92:12.1: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo tīhi māṇavakasatehi saddhiṁ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn92:12.2: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo te māṇavake āmantesi:
root_text.mn92:12.4: durāsadā hi te bhagavanto sīhāva ekacarā.
root_text.mn92:12.5: Yadā cāhaṁ, bho, samaṇena gotamena saddhiṁ manteyyaṁ, mā me bhonto antarantarā kathaṁ opātetha.
root_text.mn92:13.1: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn92:13.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn92:13.3: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho selo brāhmaṇo bhagavato kāye dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni samannesi.
root_text.mn92:13.4: Addasā kho selo brāhmaṇo bhagavato kāye dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
root_text.mn92:13.5: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—
root_text.mn92:13.8: “passati kho me ayaṁ selo brāhmaṇo dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
root_text.mn92:13.9: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—
root_text.mn92:14.1: Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṁ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkhāsi, yathā addasa selo brāhmaṇo bhagavato kosohitaṁ vatthaguyhaṁ.
root_text.mn92:14.2: Atha kho bhagavā jivhaṁ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi; ubhopi nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi; kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṁ jivhāya chādesi.
root_text.mn92:15.2: “samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paripuṇṇehi, no aparipuṇṇehi;
root_text.mn92:15.3: no ca kho naṁ jānāmi buddho vā no vā.
root_text.mn92:15.4: Sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
root_text.mn92:15.5: ‘ye te bhavanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā te sake vaṇṇe bhaññamāne attānaṁ pātukarontī’ti.
root_text.mn92:15.6: Yannūnāhaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthaveyyan”ti.
root_text.mn92:15.7: Atha kho selo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
root_text.mn92:24.1: Alattha kho selo brāhmaṇo sapariso bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.
root_text.mn92:25.1: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo tassā rattiyā accayena sake assame paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṁ ārocāpesi:
root_text.mn92:25.3: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena keṇiyassa jaṭilassa assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena.
root_text.mn92:25.4: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo buddhappamukhaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi, sampavāresi.
root_text.mn92:25.5: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo bhagavantaṁ bhuttāviṁ onītapattapāṇiṁ aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn92:25.6: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho keṇiyaṁ jaṭilaṁ bhagavā imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
root_text.mn92:26.9: Atha kho bhagavā keṇiyaṁ jaṭilaṁ imāhi gāthāhi anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn92:27.1: Atha kho āyasmā selo sapariso eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.mn92:27.2: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.mn92:27.3: Aññataro kho panāyasmā selo sapariso arahataṁ ahosi.
root_text.mn92:28.1: Atha kho āyasmā selo sapariso yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṁ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:

translation_text.mn92:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants in the land of the Aṅguttarāpans when he arrived at a town of theirs named Āpaṇa.
translation_text.mn92:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
translation_text.mn92:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn92:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn92:2.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn92:2.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn92:3.1: So Keṇiya approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn92:3.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn92:3.3: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.mn92:3.4: Then he said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn92:3.5: “Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
translation_text.mn92:3.6: When he said this, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn92:3.7: “The Saṅgha is large, Keṇiya; there are 1,250 mendicants. And you are devoted to the brahmins.”
translation_text.mn92:3.8: For a second time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
translation_text.mn92:3.9: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.
translation_text.mn92:3.10: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
translation_text.mn92:3.11: And for a second time, the Buddha gave the same reply.
translation_text.mn92:3.13: For a third time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
translation_text.mn92:3.14: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.
translation_text.mn92:3.15: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
translation_text.mn92:4.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and went to his own hermitage. There he addressed his friends and colleagues, relatives and kin,
translation_text.mn92:4.2: “My friends and colleagues, relatives and kin: please listen!
translation_text.mn92:4.3: The ascetic Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal.
translation_text.mn92:4.4: Please help me out with the manual preparations.”
translation_text.mn92:4.5: “Yes, worthy sir,” they replied. Some dug ovens, some chopped wood, some washed dishes, some set out a water jar, and some spread out seats.
translation_text.mn92:4.6: Meanwhile, Keṇiya set up the pavilion himself.
translation_text.mn92:5.1: Now at that time the brahmin Sela was residing in Āpaṇa. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. And he was teaching three hundred young students to recite the hymns.
translation_text.mn92:6.1: And at that time Keṇiya was devoted to Sela.
translation_text.mn92:6.2: Then Sela, while going for a walk escorted by the three hundred young students, approached Keṇiya’s hermitage.
translation_text.mn92:6.3: He saw the preparations going on,
translation_text.mn92:7.2: “Keṇiya, is your son or daughter being married? Or are you setting up a big sacrifice? Or has King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha been invited for tomorrow’s meal?”
translation_text.mn92:8.1: “There is no marriage, Sela, and the king is not coming.
translation_text.mn92:8.2: Rather, I am setting up a big sacrifice.
translation_text.mn92:8.3: The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
translation_text.mn92:8.5: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn92:8.6: He has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”
translation_text.mn92:9.1: “Worthy Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?”
translation_text.mn92:10.2: “It’s hard to even find the word ‘awakened one’ in the world.
translation_text.mn92:10.3: The thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
translation_text.mn92:10.4: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.
translation_text.mn92:10.5: He has the following seven treasures:
translation_text.mn92:10.6: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.
translation_text.mn92:10.7: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
translation_text.mn92:10.8: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
translation_text.mn92:10.9: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who casts off the veil from the world.”
translation_text.mn92:11.1: “But Keṇiya, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
translation_text.mn92:11.2: When he said this, Keṇiya pointed with his right arm and said,
translation_text.mn92:11.3: “There, worthy Sela, at that line of blue forest.”
translation_text.mn92:12.1: Then Sela, together with his young students, approached the Buddha.
translation_text.mn92:12.2: He said to his young students,
translation_text.mn92:12.4: For the Buddhas are intimidating, like a lion living alone.
translation_text.mn92:12.5: When I’m consulting with the ascetic Gotama, don’t interrupt.
translation_text.mn92:13.1: Then Sela went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn92:13.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn92:13.3: and scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.
translation_text.mn92:13.4: He saw all of them except for two,
translation_text.mn92:13.6: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.
translation_text.mn92:13.7: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn92:13.8: “Sela sees all the marks except for two,
translation_text.mn92:13.10: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.”
translation_text.mn92:14.1: The Buddha used his psychic power to will that Sela would see his private parts covered in a foreskin.
translation_text.mn92:14.2: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.
translation_text.mn92:15.2: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none.
translation_text.mn92:15.3: But I don’t know whether or not he is an awakened one.
translation_text.mn92:15.4: I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said,
translation_text.mn92:15.5: ‘Those who are perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas reveal themselves when praised.’
translation_text.mn92:15.6: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
translation_text.mn92:15.7: Then Sela extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
translation_text.mn92:16.2: you’re radiant, handsome, lovely to behold;
translation_text.mn92:16.4: with teeth so white; you’re strong.
translation_text.mn92:16.7: the marks of a great man,
translation_text.mn92:16.8: are all found on your body.
translation_text.mn92:16.9: Your eyes are clear, your face is fair,
translation_text.mn92:16.11: In the midst of the Saṅgha of ascetics,
translation_text.mn92:16.13: You’re a mendicant fine to see,
translation_text.mn92:16.14: with skin that shines like lustrous gold.
translation_text.mn92:16.16: what do you want with the ascetic life?
translation_text.mn92:16.17: You’re fit to be a king,
translation_text.mn92:16.18: a wheel-turning monarch, chief of charioteers,
translation_text.mn92:16.20: lord of the Black Plum Tree Land.
translation_text.mn92:16.24: as king of kings, lord of mankind!”
translation_text.mn92:17.2: the supreme king of the teaching.

translation_text.mn92:18.6: the disciple who follows the Teacher’s way?
translation_text.mn92:19.1: “By me the wheel was rolled forth,”
translation_text.mn92:19.4: Sāriputta, taking after the Realized One,
translation_text.mn92:19.6: I have known what should be known,
translation_text.mn92:19.7: and developed what should be developed,
translation_text.mn92:19.8: and given up what should be given up:
translation_text.mn92:19.9: and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.

translation_text.mn92:19.21: I rejoice, fearing nothing from any quarter.”

translation_text.mn92:20.9: Those who wish may follow me;
translation_text.mn92:20.11: Right here, I’ll go forth in his presence,
translation_text.mn92:20.12: the one of such outstanding wisdom.”

translation_text.mn92:21.4: the one of such outstanding wisdom.”

translation_text.mn92:23.4: Here the going forth isn’t in vain
translation_text.mn92:23.5: for one who trains with diligence.”
translation_text.mn92:24.1: And the brahmin Sela together with his assembly received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.mn92:25.1: And when the night had passed Keṇiya had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own hermitage. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
translation_text.mn92:25.2: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”
translation_text.mn92:25.3: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Keṇiya’s hermitage, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn92:25.4: Then Keṇiya served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
translation_text.mn92:25.5: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Keṇiya took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.mn92:25.6: The Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:
translation_text.mn92:26.1: “The foremost of sacrifices <j>is the offering to the sacred flame;
translation_text.mn92:26.2: the Sāvitrī is the foremost of prayer;
translation_text.mn92:26.3: of humans, the king is the foremost;
translation_text.mn92:26.4: the ocean’s the foremost of rivers;
translation_text.mn92:26.5: the foremost of stars is the moon;
translation_text.mn92:26.6: the sun is the foremost of blazes;
translation_text.mn92:26.7: for those who sacrifice seeking merit,
translation_text.mn92:26.9: When the Buddha had expressed his appreciation to Keṇiya the matted-hair ascetic with these verses, he got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.mn92:27.1: Then Venerable Sela and his assembly, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They lived having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn92:27.2: They understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.mn92:27.3: And Venerable Sela together with his assembly became perfected.
translation_text.mn92:28.1: Then Sela with his assembly went to see the Buddha. He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:
translation_text.mn92:28.3: we went for refuge, O Clear-eyed One.
translation_text.mn92:28.4: In these seven days, Blessed One,
translation_text.mn92:28.5: we’ve become tamed in your teaching.
translation_text.mn92:28.6: You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,
translation_text.mn92:28.7: you are the sage who has overcome Māra;
translation_text.mn92:28.8: you have cut off the underlying tendencies,
translation_text.mn92:28.9: you’ve crossed over, and you bring humanity across.
translation_text.mn92:28.12: by not grasping, like a lion,
translation_text.mn92:28.13: you’ve given up fear and dread.
translation_text.mn92:28.16: Stretch out your feet, great hero:
translation_text.mn92:28.17: let these giants bow to the Teacher.”
